body.p:
Covington Kentucky
March 26. 1861
Governor Magoffin
My Dear Sir

I write in behalf of James and Thomas Fitsgerald who have been convicted at term of our Court for shooting without doing injury and ordered to six months confinement in the County Jail and to pay $100 apiece I ^do not^ believe that they shot at all. They were trying to dispossess a tenant and undetook to force their way into the house in order to serve a notice, and behaved badly and have been punished a good deal already and ought to pay $50 each, of the fines. Upon a subsiquent trial of an Indictment against one of them for carrying the pistol, the other testified against the two witnesses of the Commonwealth, and the Jury could not agree. I am not in the habit of signing petitions to your Excellency, and would not write this, if I did not sincerely believe, that those men were no further guilty than as above suggested. Mr Arthur, who has conduced to discontinue the case in which the Jury disagreed, will add a postscript.
P. S. accompanying this is a statement of Jurymen

p.note: I send you one of the shot which was said to have been sent by the pistol through a pane of glass and lodged within 2 feet of the window on a table

body.p: I am of the opinion that the fine is sufficient punishment and that the imprisonment might properly be discharged. Mr Menzies is mistaken in his statement in the foregoing petition that I have concluded to discontinue the Indictment against one of the Defendants as to which a Jury disagreed, I have, however, that step under advisement -- this note is written at the request of Mr Menzies

W. E. Arthur
Atty for Com'th

Since writing the foregoing, I have seen eight of the Jurors -- 4 of whom wished the imprisonment and half the fines taken and 4 were for retaining the whole of the fines. The other 4 I could not see conveniently and did not see them. I will remark here, that men were fined ten dollars each for injuring property, that is breaking the pane of glass. They are worth worth nothing but 17 acres of land 3 1/2 miles from Covington= $1200. subject to a bona fide mortgage of about $800, and a note on a good man for $200, I believe that they are honest men.
I cheerfully concur in the foregoing petition I heard the testimony about the shot

Kenton Cir. Ct
To Gov. Magoffin
Remitted as to imprisonment & respite fine 6 mos

Shooting
James & Thos. Fitzgerald
Iss Apr 11. 1861
